description: From French réticule, from Latin reticulum, diminutive of rēte (“net”).

entries.meaning: A reticle; a grid in the eyepiece of an instrument. [from 18th c.]
examples: [H]er hair had been used to create the reticule in the famous Norden bombsight—a top-secret WWII targeting device.

entries.meaning: A small women's bag made of a woven net-like material. [from 19th c.]
examples: Pléiade  […]  lingered through another bottle of wine before producing from her reticule a Vacheron & Constantin watch  […] .
